measured_by: children’s responses on a three-point confidence rating scale (very sure / a little bit sure / not sure)
justification: “To address this, we used a scale… which asks children to report how ‘sure’ they are on a three-point scale… Sensitivity to uncertainty is indicated when children use the different scale values to appropriately distinguish among the levels of ambiguity present.”

measured_by: two- or three-point confidence scales asking how ‘sure’ they are
justification: “This is typically measured by asking children to explicitly report how ‘sure’ they are about an outcome… using a scale with two or three fixed-points, corresponding to greater or lesser confidence.”
“This ability has been found in a number of different behaviors, including the amount of selfallocated study time (Destan et al., 2014).”
“…including the amount of selfallocated study time, the tendency to seek help (Coughlin et al., 2015)…”

measured_by: decision not to have one’s judgment assessed
justification: “…including… the decision not to have one's judgment assessed…”
“…and opting-out of making the judgment at all (Lyons & Ghetti, 2013).”

measured_by: children’s forced-choice exploration of which window to reveal
justification: “Experiment 2 offers a forced choice to reveal the contents of one of the three windows… The decision to seek additional information has previously been used as an indication of uncertainty control in infants… but has never been compared to explicit uncertainty judgments.”
